bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, July 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench responds to Wood's letter, in which she informed him of her project to write the story of Walter Reed for children. He discusses his two chief discoveries: that Lazear probably was bitten deliberately and secretly, and the location of Camp Lazear. He is sending her two of his manuscripts and offers copies of some of his material. He suggests she contact Emilie Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, July 1, 1941
div1.opener:
July 1, 1941
Miss Laura Wood
1338 Nineteenth St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Miss Wood:
div1.p:
I am very interested in your letter telling of your project to
write the story of Walter Reed and the conquest of yellow fever for children.
I agree with you that this certainly does not conflict with my own efforts to
publish a longer and more detailed story for adults. I have spent four years
collecting data and by good fortune have unearthed a good amount of unpublished
material. My two chief discoveries are that Lazear was in all probability not
bitten accidentally but deliberately and secretly, and secondly, Camp Lazear,
where the work was done was lost for forty years, and Moran and I discovered it
last Fall. I have bought the little Building No. 1 which still remains and hope
to have it memorialized properly.

I am sending you by separate post two manuscripts which I have
already given. The one given on the occasion of the dedication of the Lazear Mem-
orial at Washington and Jefferson College, was published in their brochure “A
Mile Post”. It has not been published elsewhere as yet. The other was given last
month at the unveiling of the Cornwell painting at the A. M. A. We hope to pub-
lish this in Hygeia or elsewhere shortly. You are at liberty to quote this mater-
ial and I would appreciate your referring to my original articles.

Dr. Kelly gave me a great amount of material. Much of it is of
such a nature that I believe it would be entirely useless for your purpose in
writing a children's book, but some of it is of interest. However, there were
only two letters from Walter Reed therein and a couple of copies of letters from
Walter Reed to others. There were a couple of Agramonte's letters and a dozen or
two of Carroll's letters, the latter unfortunately mostly concerning his hurt
feelings that he had not been done justice. They in spots stirred up the contro-
versy as to who was the most important worker. It would seem that a thorough
appraisal of this controversy would be more my job than yours, in a book for
children. You are more interested in the straight story. I believe the best
help that you can get would be from Miss Blossom Reed, Walter Reed's daughter.
Her address is Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania. In Cleveland last months, she
showed me a manuscript which she had prepared and sent two or three places for
publication. It is a collection of letters from her father to her mother, beginning
even before their engagement to be married. It illustrates beautifully his char-
acter and adventures. Unfortunately, the letters of the Cuban period are very in-
complete as Mrs. Reed gave many of those away to various institutions and did not
make copies of them. Miss Reed permitted me to make some notes from this manuscript
but of course you would probably want to see the complete letters. I suspect that
she would let you make notes from this material, but in all fairness to her, I doubt
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
July 1, 1941
that she would want you to use this material extensively as she is still trying
to publish it, and in confidence I might say that she feels she needs the money
which she might get from the publication, and we outsiders have no right to feel
that we should interfere with that. I am taking the liberty of asking General
Kean for his permission to let me send you copies of a few letters that he has
given me--letters of Agramonte and Reed. Since you suggested it, I will also
write General Reed and Miss Hoke.

What do you wish me to do--have carbon copies or photostats made
of these various letters? The Clinic is extremely busy and will be so for the
next four months. This is our busiest season, as you can well imagine when I
tell you that over a thousand patients came in one day this week. Therefore, our
photographic department and my own secretary are working at full speed and I
regret that I cannot ask them to copy this material in hours. We would have to
make some arrangement to have it copied out of hours, either by a stenographer
or have it photostated out of hours as a private project by one of the men in our
photographic department. Doubtless, this can be done, and if you wish me to
arrange it, I will try to figure out how much it might cost.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
